questions.text: A 30-year-old young female presents to medicine OPD with complaints of sudden, unilateral painful loss of vision, and pain with ocular movement. She complains of worsening symptoms with an increase in body temperature. On examination, there is a relative afferent pupillary defect. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Optic neuritis Sudden loss of vision Pain in eye movement Worse with increased temperature Relative afferent pupillary defect All points towards Optic neuritis. Most common cause of unilateral optic neuritis in young females is multiple sclerosis and presents typically as described above.

Highyeild:

Optic neuritis- Symptoms Central smudge Pain on movement of the eye Progressive vision loss Investigation Visual acuity-loss Pinhole test- visual acuity won’t improve Ishihara color plates Color vision might be affected Swinging flashlight test- RAPD + ( Relative afferent pupillary defect ) Marcus gunn pupil Fundus examination Normal In 1/3rd patients Mild swelling of the disc

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B.NeuroMyelitisOptica - bilateral optic neuritis is found which is usually more severe. Option C. Ischemic optic neuropathy -Usually sudden, painless loss of vision Option D. Papilledema - Accompanied by signs of raised ICP and disc edema on fundoscopy.

Extraedge:

Demonstration of a relative afferent pupil defect (Marcus Gunn pupil) in the left eye, done with the patient fixating on a distant target. With dim background lighting, the pupils are equal and relatively large. Shining a flashlight into the right eye evokes equal, strong constriction of both pupils. Swinging the flashlight over to the damaged left eye causes dilation of both pupils, although they remain smaller than in A. Swinging the flashlight back over to the healthy right eye would result in symmetric constriction back to the appearance shown in B. Note that the pupils always remain equal; the damage to the left retina/ optic nerve is revealed by weaker bilateral pupil constriction to a flashlight in the left eye compared with the right eye

questions.text: A 38-year-old female presented with a history of headaches and diplopia in the last 2-3 weeks. Extraocular movement testing is shown below. Which nerve is affected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left 3rd nerve palsy The clinical photograph shows Left-sided ptosis Restricted adduction movement of left eyeball Normal abduction movement of left eyeball These are suggestive of left-sided isolated third nerve palsy.

Highyeild:

3rd nerve palsy Eye abducted,depressed and Mydriatic(Down and out eye) Outermost fibers of 3rd nerve Supply pupil Affected in compression 3rd nerve palsy sparing pupil Vasculitis Diabetes mellitus 3rd nerve palsy evaluation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Right 6th nerve palsy -will cause the failure of abduction of the eye. Right 3rd nerve palsy- The right eye adduction and elevation are normal in this patient and there is NO ptosis on the Right side hence right side 3rd nerve is normal OptionD.Left 6th nerve palsy- will cause failure of abduction of the Left eye and the head will be turned on the same side as the 6th nerve palsy.

Extraedge:

Presentation Diplopia increases on which gaze? Diplopia increases on which side head tilt Muscle damaged Right hypertropia Right gaze Right tilt LIO Left tilt RIR Left gaze Right tilt RSO Left tilt LSR Left hypertropia Right gaze Right tilt RSR Left tilt LSO Left gaze Right tilt LIR Left tilt RIO Abbreviations- R-Right L-Left I-Inferior S-Superior O-oblique R-Rectus

questions.text: A 54-Year-old male presents with diplopia which he noticed for the last 1-2 months. On examination, it is noted that diplopia persists even after either eye is covered. All the following can cause these clinical findings EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myasthenia Gravis Diplopia persists in either eye after the opposite eye is covered . So, the diagnosis is monocular diplopia. Myasthenia gravis causes Binocular diplopia.

Highyeild:

Double vision/Diplopia Binocular Resolve after covering 1 eye Restrictive orbital disease Myasthenia gravis. Monocular Persist after covering 1 eye Ocular cause Corneal aberrations Keratoconus Pterygium Uncorrected refractive error Cataract foveal traction Malingering psychiatric disease.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B, C, and D cause Monocular Diplopia.

Extraedge:

Presentation Diplopia increases on which gaze? Diplopia increases on which side head tilt Muscle damaged Right hypertropia Right gaze Right tilt LIO Left tilt RIR Left gaze Right tilt RSO Left tilt LSR Left hypertropia Right gaze Right tilt RSR Left tilt LSO Left gaze Right tilt LIR Left tilt RIO Abbreviations- R-Right L-Left I-Inferior S-Superior O-oblique R-Rectus

questions.text: Match the Following pairs of yolk muscles of the eye:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

a-2 b-3 c-1 d-4 a.Right medial rectus Left lateral rectus b.Right superior oblique Left inferior rectus c.Right Superior rectus Left inferior oblique d. Left medial rectus Right lateral rectus

Highyeild:

Yolk muscles - Contralaterally paired extraocular muscles that work synergistically to direct the gaze in a given direction. For example, in directing the gaze to the right , the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus operate together as yoke muscles. The yolk pair muscles of the eye and their functions are shown below: Position of eyes YOKE muscle Up and Right RSR and LIO Up and Left LSR and RIO Right RLR and LMR Left LLR and RMR Down and right RIR and LSO Down and left LIR and RSO Abbreviations- ● R-Right L-Left ● I-Inferior S-Superior ● O-oblique R-Rectus

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A, C, and D are not the correct match.

questions.text: The following shown visual field defect can be seen with which of the following sites of lesion?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left temporal lobe The image shows a Right homonymous superior quadrantanopia. A lesion in the left temporal lobe can produce this kind of visual field defect Damage to the optic radiations in the temporal lobe ( Meyer's loop) produce this kind of visual field defect which is also called “Pie in the Sky”

Highyeild:

' Ventral view of the brain, correlating patterns of visual field loss with the sites of lesions in the visual pathway.By convention, the visual fields are always recorded with the left eye’s field on the left and the right eye’s field on the right, just as the patient sees the world.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A.Injury to the right parietal lobe will lead to a left homonymous inferior quadrantanopia(Pie on the floor) Option B.Injury to the left parietal lobe will lead to a right homonymous inferior quadrantanopia (Pie on the floor) Option C.Injury to right temporal lobe will lead to a left homonymous superior quadrantanopia(Pie in the sky)

Extraedge:

Lesion on and beyond Optic chiasma causes Homonymous visual field defect.
